A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.

For an element $a \in M$ of a monoid and an exponent $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the $n$th power of $a$, denoted $a^n$, is defined in the usual way. Note that $a^0 = e$, following the convention on empty products.
Does the concept of a/an Cyclic group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Powers of an Element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of the Powers of an Element involves taking an element from a monoid (which includes groups as a special case) and repeatedly applying the monoid operation to it. This concept is defined independently of the structure of the monoid or group being cyclic. A cyclic group, by definition, is a group that can be generated by a single element, meaning every element of the group can be expressed as some power of this generator. However, the definition of powers of an element does not rely on the group being cyclic; it only requires the existence of a monoid operation and an identity element. Thus, the concept of a cyclic group is not necessary for the definition of powers of an element to make sense. The powers of an element can be defined in any monoid, whether or not it forms a cyclic group.
